In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Here is the definition of the `clean_column` function in Julia that performs the specified cleaning operations on a column name:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    # Lowercase the string
    str = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    str = strip(str)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    str = replace(str, " " => "_")
    str = replace(str, "-" => "_")
    
    return str
end
```

This function takes a `AbstractString` as input and returns the cleaned version of the column name. It first lowercases the string to ensure consistency in case sensitivity. Then it strips any leading or trailing whitespaces using `strip(str)`, which removes all characters matching `iswhitespace()` from both ends of the string. Finally, it replaces spaces (`" "`) and hyphens (`"-"`) with underscores (`"_"`) using `replace(str, " " => "_")` and `replace(str, "-" => "_")`, respectively.

To use this function, simply call it with the column name you want to clean:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```

This will return the cleaned column name "my\_column" as expected.
